body.name: The Gentleman and the Spy: A Victorian MM Romance (Ormond Yard Romantic Adventures Book 1)

productInformation.name: Best Sellers Rank
productInformation.value: #98,407 in Kindle Store (See Top 100 in Kindle Store) #360 in Historical British Fiction #544 in Historical British & Irish Literature #749 in Historical Regency Fiction

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on February 11, 2021
reviews.reviewTitle: 5.0 out of 5 stars Another Top Notch Effort
reviews.reviewText: With two excellent series behind him ("Mahu and "Have Body, Will Guard") Neil Plakcy could be forgiven if he came up with a bit of a miss when he tackles historical fiction for the first time.But Plakcy is dependable in so many ways that it's only a few pages into this one that you realize we have another two totally opposite, yet completely compatible, MCs to entrance us.That he manages to do it while immersing us in a perfect Victorian England setting with all its social complexities and foibles laid bare for our entertainment--and disgust--is all the more remarkable.In Lord Magnus Dawson (on the cover, woof!) and the commoner Toby Marsh Plakcy has given us a perfectly wonderful pairing who have their pride and prejudice issues but also pent up desires to find the right man.That they come together as Lord and valet in a mystery that is not as complicated as it seems but still neatly laid out and done over, is an achievement that may have floundered in the hands of a less experienced author.This one has the seedlings of a series, but even if it doesn't turn out that way it's another pleasant ride for Plakcy fans and a must read for those who have not had the pleasure of his craft as yet.

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on February 5, 2024
reviews.reviewTitle: 4.0 out of 5 stars Defying The Class Hierarchy!
reviews.reviewText: A fortuitous meeting changes the lives of Lord Magnus Dawson and Toby Marsh. I love historical romantic stories. This one is no exception. It has intrigue, secrets, a murder, and also sexy bits. My only critique: I didn’t feel the romantic connection between the MCs, so when the “I’m so in love” scene appeared, it felt a little abrupt. Their connection felt more like lust than love. Overall, solid storytelling and a likable read.

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on March 23, 2021
reviews.reviewTitle: 5.0 out of 5 stars A very rewarding read!
reviews.reviewText: M/M fiction has mostly fallen into a rut lately, but I found The Gentleman and the Spy to show much more originality than I've sadly grown used to. One of the giveaways that I would enjoy this book was that the plot of the mystery was destined to peak earlier than is usual, which is a good sign, because it shows that the book has created interesting characters the writer is not willing to let go of in a curt, facile, one-line wrap up. Indeed, the whodonit part of the story is a little clunky, while still entertaining. But it is later that I began to develop a fondness for many of the players, and not just the two main men. I certainly hope that the book is setting us up for further adventures of Magnus and Toby.The one thing that made me squirm at regular intervals was the use of the word "homosexual." I never actually picked an exact date for the book's setting, but this word did not enter even the scientific world in England until the first decade of the 20th century, and it would be far later that it would find it's way into conversational use. Such care was used in choosing other marvelous words:"Toby rested his wet umbrella in the majolica stand by the door..." that this one fell clumsily amidst the gifts.

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on May 5, 2022
reviews.reviewTitle: 5.0 out of 5 stars A Victorian mystery/romance
reviews.reviewText: There are a great many Regency novels, but relatively few of the late Victorian era (somewhere between 1875 and 1900). It was very interesting to read this. The romance was lovely, but also integral to the plot. I do hope the author will consider putting Toby and Magnus in more adventures together! Definitely Recommended!

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on February 9, 2021
reviews.reviewText: As I read this I kept thinking of the amazing Think of England, by KJ Charles, set in a similar time period with a similar feel plot. It was light and bright and amazing. This felt plodding and pedestrian. I finished it, so that's an automatic 3 star rating for me, but it was too prosaic, and the plot was more interesting than the romance and the ending made no sense at all. Disappointing.

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on April 29, 2021
reviews.reviewTitle: 4.0 out of 5 stars Fun and interesting mystery romance
reviews.reviewText: My only complaint is wishing more of the mystery aspect of the plot to be more drawn out. Other than that, I became quickly attached to the main duo and would love to read more of them.

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on November 12, 2022
reviews.reviewText: I totally enjoy this writers craft of developing characters and plot. The story is kept moving and you don't find yourself wanting to skim over the boring parts. Thoroughly enjoyable read from start to finish.

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on April 19, 2021
reviews.reviewTitle: 5.0 out of 5 stars A change of pace from Neil Plakcy
reviews.reviewText: Having been a fan of his three other contemporary M/M murder-mystery series, I was intrigued by this period piece. Neil Plakcy creates a vivid Victorian era murder mystery, introducing us to another pair of interesting and well-drawn heroes -- Magnus and Toby. Bringing opposites together is a Plakcy specialty and these two are certainly an intriguing pair. I look forward to seeing more of these two and how they navigate the social structure of Victorian England as a same-sex partnership.

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on March 10, 2021
reviews.reviewTitle: Great fun and a fascinating romance in Victorian England
reviews.reviewText: Our two protagonists are specially chosen to undertake a spying mission at a shooting party at a country house in the Cotswolds. It is not the usual master/servant relationship; the aristocrat is picked purely because of his status and family connections whist his 'valet' has a degree and speaks fluent French. They fall in love but can Victorian society ever accept their relationship? There is a crime, an arrest and a case to solve. There are also financial restraints. It is a thoroughly entertaining read and I am happy to recommend it.

I enjoyed this romp, mainly for the characterizations and period descriptions. The characters are well drawn and not one dimensional. I dropped a star for the too pat ending/solution and for the mystery being a little too easy to solve. However, as a first book in this series, I was pleased and have high hopes for any sequels.

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on October 1, 2021
reviews.reviewText: I'm new to the author so I didn't know what to expect but thankfully I was completely surprised by the writing and effort put into it. I enjoyed both Toby and Magnus as well as the minor characters. I thought Plakcy dealt with Toby's character extremely well especially when writing about his trauma. Magnus was lovely too, he grew on me. I look forward to the author's other books.

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on February 6, 2021
reviews.reviewTitle: Oh dear, my one and only Mr Plakcy 😕
reviews.reviewText: Not the best historical whodunit/spy mystery I've ever read unfortunately. The perpetrator was fairly well telegraphed, the two MC's fell in insta-love quite quickly, and there were several errors, not just grammatical, together with some pretty dreadful formatting...just take a look at the cast of characters for example. Won't be bothering with Mr Plakcy again I'm afraid 😕.

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on May 13, 2022
reviews.reviewText: This is an interesting mystery and romance combined, telling us how m/m relationships could be managed even when prohibited by law. The two men involved are of different classes but overcome those boundaries to work together and to love each other. Well written and enjoyable.
